sections.title: Tell us what happened
sections.description: Use this section of the form to explain how the criminal facilitation of tax evasion took place.

fields.infoText: For the facilitation of tax evasion to be a criminal act, a person must have deliberately and dishonestly helped another person to evade tax. This doesn’t include the accidental, ignorant or negligent facilitation of tax evasion.

fields.label: Summarise how the tax evasion was facilitated
In what capacity was the person responsible acting?
Any other information you feel may be relevant
Have you made any other report, such as a Suspicious Activity Report to any other body or agency?
Tell us who you’ve informed about the tax evasion
Enter any reference numbers associated with these reports (optional)

choices: I confirm that I am authorised to make this report and understand that I may commit a criminal offence if I give wrong information or include information that I don't honestly believe to be true.

fields.infoText:
Personal data collected from this form will be processed in accordance with the Data Protection Act 2018. For more information, on what data the HMRC will collect and how it is used, please see our External Privacy Notice. 

If the information submitted leads to an investigation, we may pass your contact details to the relevant HMRC investigation team. We will only pass on these details with your consent, or when a legal or other overriding obligation to do so arises. 

If you do not consent, all further contact with you will be handled by ???????? and the information you give us will be anonymised (as far as possible) before being passed to the investigation team. 

Please select one of the following options:

choices: I give my permission for my personal data to be passed to any relevant HMRC investigation team
I do not give permission for my personal data to be passed to any relevant HMRC investigation team, but understand you will do so if obliged

fields.infoText:
HMRC may need to pass on the information you supplied for legal, regulatory or operational reasons. For example, we may pass the information to the police, local authorities or other government departments. 
Again, we will only pass on your personal data or identifying information with your explicit consent, or in the rare circumstances where a legal or other overriding obligation to do so arises. If we are able to notify you about this, we will do so as soon as practicable. 

Please select one of the following options:

choices: I give my permission for HMRC to share my personal data or identifying information in the circumstances described above
I do not give permission for HMRC to share my personal data or identifying information, but understand that the HMRC will do so if obliged.

fields.infoText: We recommend you keep the acknowledgement of completion and a copy of your self report for future reference. (new line) You may not hear again from an officer of HMRC for some time, or at all. HMRC may use information in your report to make a decision whether to start a criminal investigation, and might use evidence in your report in a prosecution or other court proceedings. Where the law permits, HMRC may also share the information in your self-report with other agencies.
